Change-Id: I82e2bbf7e0380e2bffbb44d394e9751e1578afcf
'}, {'created': '2022-06-08 21:11:50.000000000', 'message': "DNM: use stable/yoga requirements for CI jobs

cinderlib master is still Yoga development, but requirements master
has moved on to Zed development ... which hasn't mattered much in the
past, but python 3.6 has been supported on Rocky through Yoga, and is
dropped from Zed.  I think we should have been using the stable branch
in cinderlib's pre-release trailing phase all along; it just hasn't
mattered until now.

Change-Id: I82e2bbf7e0380e2bffbb44d394e9751e1578afcf
"}, {'created': '2022-06-08 23:21:44.000000000', 'message': "Use stable/yoga override for CI jobs

cinderlib master is still Yoga development, but when zuul runs on a
master patch, zuul.branch is 'master', and this cascades throughout
the various jobs.  It's particularly evident for requirements, but
also affects cinder and os-brick (which are installed from source);
from what I can tell, an initial install is done to gather
dependencies, and this seems to be from master by default.  So
explicitly use override-checkout for requirements, cinder, and
os-brick on all jobs.

Why are we only noticing this now?  I think it hasn't been a problem
in the past because python 3.6 has been supported from Rocky through
Yoga, and is dropped from Zed, and hence running the cinderlib Yoga
development branch against master for other projects is encountering
some serious incompatibilities.  We probably should have been using
the stable branch in cinderlib's pre-release trailing phase all
along; it just hasn't mattered until now.

Change-Id: I82e2bbf7e0380e2bffbb44d394e9751e1578afcf
"}]
commit_message:
Use stable/yoga override for CI jobs

cinderlib master is still Yoga development, but when zuul runs on a
master patch, zuul.branch is 'master', and this cascades throughout
the various jobs.  It's particularly evident for requirements, but
also affects cinder and os-brick (which are installed from source);
from what I can tell, an initial install is done to gather
dependencies, and this seems to be from master by default.  So
explicitly use override-checkout for requirements, cinder, and
os-brick on all jobs.

Why are we only noticing this now?  I think it hasn't been a problem
in the past because python 3.6 has been supported from Rocky through
Yoga, and is dropped from Zed, and hence running the cinderlib Yoga
development branch against master for other projects is encountering
some serious incompatibilities.  We probably should have been using
the stable branch in cinderlib's pre-release trailing phase all
along; it just hasn't mattered until now.

Change-Id: I82e2bbf7e0380e2bffbb44d394e9751e1578afcf

36ac1ea55271e1523c35862f76e6e3013f18e8ea ("Remove Ocata's data
migrations") and can be removed now.

Change-Id: I164f19abf6a5da5dfda21b812c0c39fdab0cc7c7
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
db: Remove unused API

The 'cg_cgsnapshot_destroy_all_by_ids' API has been unused since commit
36ac1ea55271e1523c35862f76e6e3013f18e8ea ("Remove Ocata's data
migrations") and can be removed now.

Change-Id: I164f19abf6a5da5dfda21b812c0c39fdab0cc7c7
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

subject: db: Remove final users of 'get_session'

commit_message:
db: Remove final users of 'get_session'

We also update 'get_engine' to avoid calling 'get_legacy_facade'.

Change-Id: Ic8c37145c66069e9194458fa7f622d98022fee4f
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
WIP: Install libselinux-3.4-2 from centos-compose

libselinux-3.4-1.el9.x86_64.rpm broke the check, gate and
integration CS9 line.

The fix will be available in libselinux-3.4-2 (will take some time to
available on AFS mirror), till then we need to install it from
the CentOS Stream production compose itself.

The fix is copied from
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/diskimage-builder/+/845189

Change-Id: Iccd4bbe02faad8b483d250eeaffefd9288d40c67
Related-Bug: #1977888

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-05-25 10:10:37.000000000', 'message': '[sqlalchemy-20] Use session.transaction information to decide if active

The "session.transaction" members "_new", "_dirty" and "_deleted" are
a "WeakKeyDictionary" that holds the pending operations in this active
transaction. If any of those dictionaries have any element, the session
is considered as active.

Closes-Bug: #1975542
Change-Id: Ibb75b324950c639d30c77d4e5269a8c53d6a0bb5
'}, {'created': '2022-05-30 08:23:45.000000000', 'message': '[sqlalchemy-20] Use session.transaction information to decide if active

The "session.transaction" member "_connections" is a dictionary with the active
database connections of the current transaction. Neutron will use it to determine
if the session is active or not. This parameter will provide more accurate
information than "new", "dirty" or "deleted". A read (SELECT) operation won't
be included on those lists while the transaction is currently active.

Closes-Bug: #1975542
Change-Id: Ibb75b324950c639d30c77d4e5269a8c53d6a0bb5
'}, {'created': '2022-05-30 08:24:43.000000000', 'message': '[sqlalchemy-20] Use session.transaction information to decide if active

The "session.transaction" member "_connections" is a dictionary with the
active database connections of the current transaction. Neutron will use
it to determine if the session is active or not. This parameter will
provide more accurate information than "new", "dirty" or "deleted". A
read (SELECT) operation won't be included on those lists while the
transaction is currently active.

Closes-Bug: #1975542
Change-Id: Ibb75b324950c639d30c77d4e5269a8c53d6a0bb5
'}, {'created': '2022-06-08 08:21:34.000000000', 'message': '[sqlalchemy-20] Use session.transaction information to decide if active

The "session.transaction" member "_connections" is a dictionary with the
active database connections of the current transaction. Neutron will use
it to determine if the session is active or not. This parameter will
provide more accurate information than "new", "dirty" or "deleted". A
read (SELECT) operation won't be included on those lists while the
transaction is currently active.

Closes-Bug: #1975542
Change-Id: Ibb75b324950c639d30c77d4e5269a8c53d6a0bb5
'}]
commit_message:
[sqlalchemy-20] Use session.transaction information to decide if active

The "session.transaction" member "_connections" is a dictionary with the
active database connections of the current transaction. Neutron will use
it to determine if the session is active or not. This parameter will
provide more accurate information than "new", "dirty" or "deleted". A
read (SELECT) operation won't be included on those lists while the
transaction is currently active.

Closes-Bug: #1975542
Change-Id: Ibb75b324950c639d30c77d4e5269a8c53d6a0bb5

commit_message:
Add an IPv6 tunnel endpoint job definition

Uses the new devstack-ipv6-all job definition so that IPv6
is used on the tunnel endpoints as well.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/710519
Change-Id: Ifde9564f92d08317e630eb8d254ac9d7d9141986

commit_message:
Add get-or-create-user and delete-user actions for ceph auth

The get-or-create-user action allows to create and get user,
with its mon and osd capabilities, and retrieve the related
keyring.
The delete-user action allows to delete users.

Closes-Bug: 1899215
func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/765
Change-Id: I2bd148e442990b6ff978624023bd85a741c6259a

commit_message:

should be made voting again later.

commit_message:
multipath/iscsi: iSCSI connections are not reinitiated after reboot

After compute host reboot, in an iSCSI/multipath environment, some
of the connections to the iSCSI portal are not reinitiated and missing
iSCSI devices are observed. This patchset introduced retries for this
particular scenario.

Closes-Bug: #1944474
Change-Id: I60ee7421f7b792e8324286908a9fdd8fb53e433e
(cherry picked from commit 8832c5389964973084cd0f80a2d8f7f24255ea3f)
(cherry picked from commit 4d116483aff6efa425cd1b7b00e87f6385a9a725)

(cherry picked from commit 7c7650b4de9fa319c8c42423502ccd55a510a417)
(cherry picked from commit d0eea8a6eb5a620d405dc819eb2285a9e242f4a3)

commit_message:
Add periodic-stable-jobs template

Periodic stable jobs (one py3 and a docs job) are not running towards
placement. This patch adds the template to .zuul.yaml

Conflicts:
  .zuul.yaml

NOTE(elod.illes): conflict is due to branch specific job template name.

Change-Id: Ia9dce4590d5656f8d5f777e158a1ff67c059c87a
(cherry picked from commit a0749aec17d1663c58b23d470ad9f56684d5d590)

commit_message:
Pin diskimage-builder version due to drop Python3.6

Since Ibdbcf459608711ac64e7fefb1707f6708d68e750 merged to master we
need to pin diskimage-builder to latest stable tag with support of
the Python3.6 until we move to CentOS9.

Change-Id: I9f9e381716611b71584ecf8b371f8b7f45c694ee
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 1b259ecc5bbbe48e083a08d2e67f42887bc2eec3)

commit_message:
Use the new image naming scheme by default

Adds a relevant reno to inform users about the change and the
possibility to customise the prefix.

Additionally, this patch includes the fix to Ubuntu image builds
regarding rabbitmq and erlang.

Both the changes are required to fix master CI.

Change-Id: I6bc8b489a810849744c8bead6b9e350c5d3e36b7
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/843752

commit_message:
Rollback quota when share network create API fails.

During share network create API, if failure occurs quota is not rolled
back and its usable only after quota reservations timed out (waiting
conf.reservation_expire seconds).

Closes-bug: #1975483
Change-Id: I3de8f5bfa6ac4580da9b1012caa25657a6df71ec

[{'created': '2022-04-30 20:58:56.000000000', 'message': 'Drop lower-constraints.txt and its testing

As discussed in TC PTG[1] and TC resolution[2], we are
dropping the lower-constraints.txt file and its testing.
We will keep lower bounds in the requirements.txt file but
with a note that these are not tested lower bounds and we
try our best to keep them updated.

[1] https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tc-zed-ptg#L326
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20220414-drop-lower-constraints.html#proposal

Change-Id: I703229320320295b4a90e72c543f8959f85daaa9
'}]
commit_message:
Drop lower-constraints.txt and its testing

As discussed in TC PTG[1] and TC resolution[2], we are
dropping the lower-constraints.txt file and its testing.
We will keep lower bounds in the requirements.txt file but
with a note that these are not tested lower bounds and we
try our best to keep them updated.

[1] https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tc-zed-ptg#L326
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20220414-drop-lower-constraints.html#proposal

Change-Id: I703229320320295b4a90e72c543f8959f85daaa9

commit_message:
Remove nova_volume_attach & nova_volume_detach methods

As tempest.scenario.manager was announced stable interface in Tempest
27.0.0[1] it can be now reused in plugins.

Replaced methods:
    * nova_volume_attach
    * nova_volume_detach

Etherpad concerning this effort:
https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tempest-scenario-manager-cleanup

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/tempest/v27.0.0.html#release-notes-27-0-0

Change-Id: I59dee33174eabb677e309f5dcae88889901953fc

commit_message:
Fix networking-sfc-tempest-multinode job

cinder was enabled while c-api not leading to
deployment failure, removing cinder from enabled
services list to fix this as the service is not
needed in this job and fix job config for subnode
as per openvswitch agent.

Also pass plugin context to l2pop.db.get_agent_by_host
as without it it fails with:-
AttributeError: 'PortChainContext' object has no attribute 'session'

Change-Id: If769e89896d85cc1626fa111f546d935da21a590

commit_message:
Add py39 job in gate

We have removed py36 and changed the gate job because of decrepated
py36 and py37 in Zed. And we should introduce py39 job, this patch adding it.

Change-Id: I799a24156455635c928880ec96e122ee03fe3f9f

commit_message:
Fix tests involving pyroute2.netns module

pyroute2 0.6.11 did some further refactoring of their module imports,
adapt some mocks to that the tests work with both the older and the new
versions.

Change-Id: I00c1b1e81c33cf93372dec21f4a9f409d784a160

[{'created': '2022-06-09 08:57:05.000000000', 'message': 'Change cache filename

The current cache filename is a combination of checkpoint file argument
with a tenant argument. This might be confusing for end user.
With this commit, cache DB will be set as checkpoint file argument
provided.

Change-Id: Ib57f5a08ea36870ff34a7d23c9cdbc9863e1186a
'}]
commit_message:
Change cache filename

The current cache filename is a combination of checkpoint file argument
with a tenant argument. This might be confusing for end user.
With this commit, cache DB will be set as checkpoint file argument
provided.

Change-Id: Ib57f5a08ea36870ff34a7d23c9cdbc9863e1186a

first fixes the template used in master for upcoming Yoga cycle.
Stable branches will be fixed separately.

commit_message:
Switch tick-tick job to upgrade from xena

Since master is zed, move tick-tick job to
upgrade from xena by skipping yoga.

This also fixes ovn-grenade-multinode-tick-tick
job.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/844477
Change-Id: Iaebb1da6ce071a705e9dd25f2fc90a5163f7c363

To be described

Closes-Bug: #1977752
Change-Id: I2c6f09548f39cadfe85e57032091a70a5bc978e5
'}, {'created': '2022-06-07 10:53:51.000000000', 'message': 'Add "max-rate" value to minimum bandwidth rules

OVS translates the QoS and associated queue registers,
attached to a port, into "tc" linux-htb classfull traffic
shaper, applied on the port.

OVS creates a "tc" root class on the port device. On top of
this root class, the queues are represented as child "tc"
classes. In order to define a "min-rate" value ("tc rate"),
a "max-rate" value ("tc ceil") must be provided and higher than
"min-rate".

By default, OVS agent QoS minimum rules do not have a "max-rate"
defined. Before this patch, any minimum bandwidth rule was
limiting the maximum rate to 100Mbit/s, that is the default value
set in "tc ceil". This patch provides the maximum "max-rate" value
for any minimum bandwidth rule.

Closes-Bug: #1977752

Change-Id: I2c6f09548f39cadfe85e57032091a70a5bc978e5

commit_message:
Add "max-rate" value to minimum bandwidth rules

OVS translates the QoS and associated queue registers,
attached to a port, into "tc" linux-htb classfull traffic
shaper, applied on the port.

OVS creates a "tc" root class on the port device. On top of
this root class, the queues are represented as child "tc"
classes. In order to define a "min-rate" value ("tc rate"),
a "max-rate" value ("tc ceil") must be provided and higher than
"min-rate".

By default, OVS agent QoS minimum rules do not have a "max-rate"
defined. Before this patch, any minimum bandwidth rule was
limiting the maximum rate to 100Mbit/s, that is the default value
set in "tc ceil". This patch provides the maximum "max-rate" value
for any minimum bandwidth rule.

Closes-Bug: #1977752

Change-Id: I2c6f09548f39cadfe85e57032091a70a5bc978e5

commit_message:
Update python testing as per zed cycle testing runtime

In Zed cycle, we have dropped the python 3.6/3.7[1] testing
and its support. Removing the py36 centos8 job as well as
updating the python classifier also to reflect the same.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/zed.html

Change-Id: I6c31cc6ab8c58f77216d869dbbcd6c68bec09b7e

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-06-05 23:22:38.000000000', 'message': 'Dedup host entries in the exported data for stacks

Do not add extra host entries for VIPs for stacks deployed off the
exported data, since it already contains those entries

This is done by setting AddVipsToEtcHosts to False.
Then a stack is deployed, no more VIPs will be added into /etc/hosts
of the targeted hosts.

Change-Id: Iba03aed76fab1977e2b51ef69e8e08a493152ed6
Closes-bug: #1911792
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit e3c118756fa056602afe47136aaae77e3170b8bc)
(cherry picked from commit b8d57c0b6c4a2935cfcf00dd7b888932aeb5436e)
'}]
commit_message:
Dedup host entries in the exported data for stacks

Do not add extra host entries for VIPs for stacks deployed off the
exported data, since it already contains those entries

This is done by setting AddVipsToEtcHosts to False.
Then a stack is deployed, no more VIPs will be added into /etc/hosts
of the targeted hosts.

Change-Id: Iba03aed76fab1977e2b51ef69e8e08a493152ed6
Closes-bug: #1911792
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit e3c118756fa056602afe47136aaae77e3170b8bc)
(cherry picked from commit b8d57c0b6c4a2935cfcf00dd7b888932aeb5436e)

commit_message:
Bump oslo.log>=5.0.0 version

In zed cycle, OpenStack projects and oslo lib
has dropped the py3.6 and py3.7 support

- https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/zed.html

With oslo not supporting the py3.6 and py3.7, we disscussed in cyborg
team, and we will remove the py3.6 and py3.7 support too, and we should
bump oslo.log>=5.0.0 to support.

Change-Id: Ie297062d3e274ff7d34af11bdc78cc7db67eb26d

commit_message:
Remove docs on deploying Ceph during overcloud deployment

We now only support deploying Ceph before overcloud deployment
as described in deployed_ceph.rst.

Remove cephadm.rst and ceph_config.rst which describe deploying
Ceph during overcloud deployment. ceph_config.rst covered use
of ceph-ansible or puppet-ceph which was deprecated so it needs
to be removed. Relevant content on configuring Ceph during the
overcloud deploy from cephadm.rst was moved to deployed_ceph.rst.

Remove or replace references to ceph_config as appropriate.
The deprecated ceph_config documentation for puppet-ceph and
ceph-ansible is still available in wallaby branch [1].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/wallaby/features/ceph_config.html

Change-Id: I521b0855bc1476e715731f4ebe0d09bb4b39963d

commit_message:
Remove py36 zuul task

200~Remove py36 zuul task

In Zed, we have dropped the python 3.6/3.7[1] testing
and its support. Removing the py36 centos8 job as well as
updating the python classifier also to reflect the same.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/zed.html
Change-Id: I96076a685482d01ed095803ff716de06afd01816

Change-Id: I8bcb0b0023f68bbb5ecc49c819684b0750c6a0f3

Update the binding host information to L3 router ports, then
we can save one time-consuming _routers_to_sync. And port
information will be updated in _ensure_host_set_on_port
after update_port.

And L3-agents do not use the port binding informations,
it should be fine to return L3-agent.

'}]
commit_message:
Save one time-consuming _routers_to_sync

Update the binding host information to L3 router ports, then
we can save one time-consuming _routers_to_sync. And port
information will be updated in _ensure_host_set_on_port
after update_port.

And L3-agents do not use the port binding informations,
it should be fine to return L3-agent.

Closes-Bug: #1976345
Change-Id: I3e900d4b028be58af8e716b53704eee6ce0828b3

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-06-08 22:46:16.000000000', 'message': 'Pull tempest helper from 28.1.0 to WB base class

The reboot_server helper method that was added to tempest [1] was part
of tempset tag 28.1.0. Downstream 16.2 limits git installation to
28.0.0 and no longer supports clone from master. Taking logic from [1]
   for reboot_server and applying it to the base whitbox test class
since there are two tests that currently leverage the method.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/commit/ea2b59ce61c03f5f7cc4e8b1f9bbace4dafdd4be

Change-Id: If01f0bd4a12717067f59d3ec2421947b64b776e2
'}]
commit_message:
Pull tempest helper from 28.1.0 to WB base class

The reboot_server helper method that was added to tempest [1] was part
of tempset tag 28.1.0. Downstream 16.2 limits git installation to
28.0.0 and no longer supports clone from master. Taking logic from [1]
   for reboot_server and applying it to the base whitbox test class
since there are two tests that currently leverage the method.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/commit/ea2b59ce61c03f5f7cc4e8b1f9bbace4dafdd4be

Change-Id: If01f0bd4a12717067f59d3ec2421947b64b776e2

commit_message:
CI: drop all CentOS Stream 8 jobs

As in Kolla - we can not support CS8 anymore due to Python 3.8+
requirement.

Change-Id: Id5567fdedf52e8808400c181e90243fee7f3e136

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-11-16 15:45:45.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Different approach to TripleO job

Instead of running the command line manually like
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/705113/, let's try starting with the
existing tripleo-ci-centos-8-standalone job (which is single node),
and later add some ansible and/or shell to make it multinode.

We're trying both approaches because we're not sure which one will
turn out to be easier.

Change-Id: I30ce52190d895192597154f780fce3fa2ea8e57f

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/705113/, let's try starting with the
existing tripleo-ci-centos-8-standalone job (which is single node),
and later add some ansible and/or shell to make it multinode.

We're trying both approaches because we're not sure which one will

commit_message:
WIP: TripleO multinode standalone job

Things we have to do for this to work:
* Paramiko (what we use to SSH into the nodeset VMs) does not support
  OpenSSH-formatted private keys. Add a pre task to convert the nodepool
  ones.

Change-Id: I30ce52190d895192597154f780fce3fa2ea8e57f
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest/+/771472
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ci/+/778069

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-19 17:09:30.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Remove use of sshtunnel

Sshtunnel was only being used to access the database in an
undercloud/overcloud environment, with tempest running on the
overcloud VM and needing to tunnel through the management network (or
control plane network?) in order to access the database on the
controller. With our eventual adpotion of multinode standalone,
tempest is running on the same host as the controller, and should be
able to access the database directly. This ptch removes the tunnelling
code and the dependency on sshtunnel.

Change-Id: Iaef6918941317eb16fee9bfdc46b930cc2cdb616
'}, {'created': '2021-02-09 15:17:36.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Remove use of sshtunnel

Sshtunnel was only being used to access the database in an
undercloud/overcloud environment, with tempest running on the
overcloud VM and needing to tunnel through the management network (or
control plane network?) in order to access the database on the
controller. With our eventual adpotion of multinode standalone,
tempest is running on the same host as the controller, and should be

Change-Id: Iaef6918941317eb16fee9bfdc46b930cc2cdb616

commit_message:
WIP: Remove use of sshtunnel

Sshtunnel was only being used to access the database in an
undercloud/overcloud environment, with tempest running on the
overcloud VM and needing to tunnel through the management network (or
control plane network?) in order to access the database on the
controller. With our eventual adpotion of multinode standalone,
tempest is running on the same host as the controller, and should be
able to access the database directly. This ptch removes the tunnelling
code and the dependency on sshtunnel.

Change-Id: Iaef6918941317eb16fee9bfdc46b930cc2cdb616

commit_message:
Simplify and rename Devstack-specific pre tasks

Since we'll soon have TripleO-specific pre tasks, rename the devstack
ones, and use the opportunity to simplify them by folding the tasks
directly into the playbook.

Change-Id: I7928d7641a2879659ed6525f92f0f2baf2fd64e1

subject: Improve requirements management
messages:
[{'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2020-12-17 15:49:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28006, 'date': '2020-12-17 15:49:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Starting automatic-ci jobs.'}, {'account_id': 28006, 'date': '2020-12-17 16:27:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Build failed (automatic-ci pipeline). To rerun just this ci comment
"seans-automatic-ci: recheck". To rerun other ci jobs comment "recheck".
Note this ci does run on "recheck".


- whitebox-multinode-multinuma-devstack https://zuul.seanmooney.info/t/openstack/build/de607c09ecaf4497a196593381ff2780 : FAILURE in 36m 50s'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2022-06-08 22:29:01.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-12-17 15:49:25.000000000', 'message': 'Improve requirements management

While working on the RPM packaging for whitebox, a few things came to
light around how we manage our requirements:

* sshtunnel is always imported, but only used in TripleO
  undercloud/overcloud environments. To avoid having to pull it into
  RDO and depend on it in our RPM packaging, make its import
  conditional. In the future, it will go away when we transition to
  standalone mulitonode for our TripleO CI job(s).

* While we are still unable to list tempest and our oslo requirements
  in requirements.txt (see commit eb43bd9), we can at least have them
  as comments with an explanation. This will make it easier to
  determine our RPM dependencies.

* In a similar vein, list tempest and our oslo requirements in
  test-requirements.txt - they need to be there because in unit test
  environments we do not expect to have tempest pre-installed.

Change-Id: I2c404719f4733d99dc4fd5a4944b190b63911a8a
'}]
commit_message:
Improve requirements management

While working on the RPM packaging for whitebox, a few things came to
light around how we manage our requirements:

* sshtunnel is always imported, but only used in TripleO
  undercloud/overcloud environments. To avoid having to pull it into
  RDO and depend on it in our RPM packaging, make its import
  conditional. In the future, it will go away when we transition to
  standalone mulitonode for our TripleO CI job(s).

* While we are still unable to list tempest and our oslo requirements
  in requirements.txt (see commit eb43bd9), we can at least have them
  as comments with an explanation. This will make it easier to
  determine our RPM dependencies.

* In a similar vein, list tempest and our oslo requirements in
  test-requirements.txt - they need to be there because in unit test
  environments we do not expect to have tempest pre-installed.

Change-Id: I2c404719f4733d99dc4fd5a4944b190b63911a8a

commit_message:
compute: give server actions proper microversion support

Previously, any server action that did not get explicitly passed a
microversion would default to 2.1. This was because the _action()
method did not determine what microversion to use with
_get_microversion_for(), but rather accepted a microversion argument
with a default value of None. Only a single caller actually used that
argument. This means that the vast majority of server actions was
actually performed at microversion 2.1. This patch makes _action() use
_get_microversion_for(), and drops the microversion argument entirely.

Change-Id: I16b4513ac00edfb657621dc266880ae69e296bbb

commit_message:
Func test for compute microversion 2.9

Compute microversion 2.9 added the `is_locked` parameter in the
response of server detail, server update, and the server reduild
action. This patch functional tests to verify this.

Story: 2007929

commit_message:
Fix rebuild_server named argument

According to the Nova API reference [1], the only non-optional
parameter to the rebuild action is the imageRef. The current
rebuild_server() method signature mandates a name and an
admin_password, which are actually optional. In addition, there are
many other possible arguments to the server rebuild action which are
not possible with the current rebuild_server() method signature.

This patch adjusts the method signature to match the API, adds a
**kwargs argument to allow for arbitrary arguments, and adds a
functional test.

rebuild_server() in the shade layer (openstack/cloud/_compute.py) is
intentionally left untouched, and can be fixed in a followup.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=rebuild-server-rebuild-action-detail#rebuild-server-rebuild-action

Change-Id: I54406f79b8e9dca02c1102ecfd1d7eedd077a022
Story: 2007932

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-06-03 23:31:24.000000000', 'message': 'Fix missing --target-project-id for transfer req

The zone transfer request set command was missing the
--target-project-id option so you cannot change the target project ID of
a zone transfer request after creation with the CLI.
This option is supported by the API and documented in the API reference
guide.
This patch adds this option.

Closes-Bug: #1977625
Change-Id: Idd570a5aef57c06971db2450fdfb823cf0c07bfd
'}]
commit_message:
Fix missing --target-project-id for transfer req

The zone transfer request set command was missing the
--target-project-id option so you cannot change the target project ID of
a zone transfer request after creation with the CLI.
This option is supported by the API and documented in the API reference
guide.
This patch adds this option.

Closes-Bug: #1977625
Change-Id: Idd570a5aef57c06971db2450fdfb823cf0c07bfd

So the neutron-tempest-ipv6-only-tunnel job I added in a dependent commit definitely used an IPv6 endpoint:

OVS.local_ip = 2001:4800:7818:104:be76:4eff:fe04:69cb

I am curious what the multinode job would do since I did noticed the MTU in the OVS agent was still 1450, so might require a change like https://review.opendev.org/#/c/343041/ in order for it to account for the IPv6 overhead.

So in short this patch did work.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2021-12-28 07:56:44.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-28 20:03:38.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for IPv6 tunnel endpoints

Currently, neutron tunnel endpoints must be IPv4 addresses,
i.e. $HOST_IP, although IPv6 endpoints are supported by most
drivers.

Create a TUNNEL_IP_VERSION variable to choose which host IP
to use, either HOST_IP or HOST_IPV6, and configure it in the
OVS and Linuxbridge agent driver files. Default is IPv4, but
the goal is to eventually setup the "IPv6-only" jobs to use
it to truly have only IPv6 addresses being used.

This behaves similar to the SERVICE_IP_VERSION option, which
can either be set to 4 or 6, but not 4+6 - the tunnel overhead
should be consistent on all systems in order not to have MTU
issues.

Change-Id: I6034278dfc17b55d7863bc4db541bbdaa983a686
'}, {'created': '2020-02-28 21:31:53.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for IPv6 tunnel endpoints

Currently, neutron tunnel endpoints must be IPv4 addresses,
i.e. $HOST_IP, although IPv6 endpoints are supported by most
drivers.

Create a TUNNEL_IP_VERSION variable to choose which host IP
to use, either HOST_IP or HOST_IPV6, and configure it in the
OVS and Linuxbridge agent driver files. Default is IPv4, but
the goal is to eventually setup the "IPv6-only" jobs to use
it to truly have only IPv6 addresses being used. It can be
over-ridden by specifying TUNNEL_ENDPOINT_IP accordingly.

This behaves similar to the SERVICE_IP_VERSION option, which
can either be set to 4 or 6, but not 4+6 - the tunnel overhead
should be consistent on all systems in order not to have MTU
issues.

Change-Id: I6034278dfc17b55d7863bc4db541bbdaa983a686

'}, {'created': '2020-04-02 00:56:11.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for IPv6 tunnel endpoints

Currently, neutron tunnel endpoints must be IPv4 addresses,
i.e. $HOST_IP, although IPv6 endpoints are supported by most
drivers.

Create a TUNNEL_IP_VERSION variable to choose which host IP
to use, either HOST_IP or HOST_IPV6, and configure it in the
OVS and Linuxbridge agent driver files. Default is IPv4, but
the goal is to eventually setup the "IPv6-only" jobs to use

can either be set to 4 or 6, but not 4+6 - the tunnel overhead
should be consistent on all systems in order not to have MTU
issues.

Must set the ML2 overlay_ip_version config option to match

commit_message:
Add support for IPv6 tunnel endpoints

Currently, neutron tunnel endpoints must be IPv4 addresses,
i.e. $HOST_IP, although IPv6 endpoints are supported by most
drivers.

Create a TUNNEL_IP_VERSION variable to choose which host IP
to use, either HOST_IP or HOST_IPV6, and configure it in the
OVS and Linuxbridge agent driver files. The default is still
IPv4, but it can be over-ridden by specifying TUNNEL_ENDPOINT_IP
accordingly.

This behaves similar to the SERVICE_IP_VERSION option, which
can either be set to 4 or 6, but not 4+6 - the tunnel overhead
should be consistent on all systems in order not to have MTU
issues.

Must set the ML2 overlay_ip_version config option to match
else agent tunnel sync RPC will not work.

Must set the OVN external_ids:ovn-encap-ip config option to
the correct address.

Updated 'devstack-ipv6-only' job definition and verification role
that will set all services and tunnels to use IPv6 addresses.

Closes-bug: #1619476

Change-Id: I6034278dfc17b55d7863bc4db541bbdaa983a686

commit_message:
Capture QEMU core dumps when possible

Some of the hardest-to-debug issues are qemu crashes deep in a nova
workflow that can't be reproduced locally. This adds a post task to
the playbook so that we capture the most recent qemu core dump, if
there is one.

Change-Id: I48a2ea883325ca920b7e7909edad53a9832fb319

commit_message:
Enhance logrotate config file generation

Actually all logrotate config files are generated dynamically using
Jinja2 templates.
But content is exactly the same, only the directory path is different
and contains the program name.

This patch keep the previous Ansible 'template' task for ansible, ceph,
global, haproxy and neutron logrotate files (cause they are customized),
but generates all other files using 'copy' task.
This avoid creating a logrotate file strictly identical to other ones
when a new Openstack service is included in Kolla-ansible.

Change-Id: If5b5b1f42368d170ebea74dd823d18920a87f8ba

commit_message:
Switch cell export to ephemeral heat

Cell export is build on top of overcloud export, and
needs a catch up with the Ephemeral Heat changes.

Related: rhbz#2089512

Co-authored-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I508880782fb55894ffd8ca7e94ec75100a7ff471
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Drop python3.6/3.7 support in testing runtime

In Zed cycle testing runtime, we are targetting to drop the
python 3.6/3.7 support, project started adding python 3.8 as minimum

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/zed.html

Change-Id: I96c0e18e78da38733d6fd1100481e825b8ed188f

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-06-08 13:04:34.000000000', 'message': 'Allow unshelve to a specific host (REST API part)

This adds support to the REST API, in a new microversion, for specifying
a destination host to unshelve server action when the server
is shelved offloaded.
This patch also supports the ability to unpin the availability_zone of an
instance that is bound to it.

Note that the functional test changes are due to those tests using the
"latest" microversion 2.91.

Implements: blueprint unshelve-to-host

Change-Id: I12d1aec2069e88680cdea77ccb4da94908826eb1
'}]
commit_message:
Allow unshelve to a specific host (REST API part)

This adds support to the REST API, in a new microversion, for specifying
a destination host to unshelve server action when the server
is shelved offloaded.
This patch also supports the ability to unpin the availability_zone of an
instance that is bound to it.

Note that the functional test changes are due to those tests using the
"latest" microversion 2.91.

Implements: blueprint unshelve-to-host

Change-Id: I12d1aec2069e88680cdea77ccb4da94908826eb1

commit_message:
Switch to Cortex-A72 cpu on AArch64

CPU model "max" fails to boot CirrOS and some other images when QEMU 7.0
is used.

Change-Id: Ie34a883ac7ae989d7f74c19b9c9ee9f08a82a35f
(cherry picked from commit c9a3dd9cd3c004e61836a252aa34b65b89038bee)

(4 comments)

/proc/cpuinfo has a different layout for different cpu archatechtures and even sometime differnt vendor on the same acrhitecutre.

you have tried to workaround that by lowercasing the keys to account for the fact that "flags" is "Flags" on power i think but you have not filtered the key by not virutalised feature which are never exposed to the guest and do not affect live migration.

this feel more like a libvirt but or as kashyap suggested that we shoul possibly be using the newer libvirt api for this rahter than something we shoudl adress via parsing /proc/cpuinfo directly.'}, {'account_id': 12203, 'date': '2020-11-23 01:52:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2020-11-23 02:21:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

So, chengsheng said on IRC that he has also done some functional tests involving live migration with this patch.  Can you please note what scenarios you've tested?"}, {'account_id': 12203, 'date': '2020-12-03 03:03:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(5 comments)

> Patch Set 8:
> 
> (6 comments)
> 
> So, chengsheng said on IRC that he has also done some functional tests involving live migration with this patch.  Can you please note what scenarios you've tested?

The cpu_mode was tested for host-model, custom, and host-passthrough.

When the cpu_mode is host-model and host-passthrough, multiple compute nodes with the same CPU features are used for the following live migration test, and the system is centos7:
1. All nodes have the same kernel and have undergone a live migration test, and they can migrate normally.
2. The kernel of some nodes is 3.10, and the kernel of other nodes is upgraded to 4.19. In this case, the CPU features under different cores are different. During live migration, nodes with different CPU features are filtered out, and vm are correctly migrated to compatible nodes.

In the case of cpu_mode as custom, only the following tests are done:
1. Add an incompatible CPU feature to cpu_model_extra_flags. When nova-compute is started, an incompatible error is expected to be reported."}, {'account_id': 12203, 'date': '2020-12-03 03:17:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2020-12-03 05:49:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(Context: here I'm removing the compareCPU() check that Nova does on destination altogether to fix a live migration bug.  QEMU and libvirt in the current versions Nova has will do the correct thing automatically on the destination.)"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-01-29 13:27:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12203, 'date': '2021-02-01 02:08:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> Patch Set 12:
> 
> As a heads-up:
> 
> A related patch: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/772917 — libvirt: Remove compareCPU() check on the destination
> 
> (Context: here I'm removing the compareCPU() check that Nova does on destination altogether to fix a live migration bug.  QEMU and libvirt in the current versions Nova has will do the correct thing automatically on the destination.)

Remove compareCPU, there will be a problem. if there are many hosts in the environment and some features are different, during live migration, if the virtual machine is scheduled to an unsupported node, libvirt returns an error and the migration is aborted, and the virtual machine is still on the original node. You may have migrated many times, and it is all scheduled to the same unsupported node, and users will be very troubled."}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2021-02-02 14:36:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> Patch Set 12:
> 
> > Patch Set 12:
> > 
> > As a heads-up:
> > 
> > A related patch: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/772917 — libvirt: Remove compareCPU() check on the destination
> > 
> > (Context: here I'm removing the compareCPU() check that Nova does on destination altogether to fix a live migration bug.  QEMU and libvirt in the current versions Nova has will do the correct thing automatically on the destination.)
> 
> Remove compareCPU, there will be a problem. if there are many hosts in the environment and some features are different, during live migration, if the virtual machine is scheduled to an unsupported node, libvirt returns an error and the migration is aborted, and the virtual machine is still on the original node. You may have migrated many times, and it is all scheduled to the same unsupported node, and users will be very troubled.

I agree on taking multiple hosts into account; with that patch.  The more robust solution is indeed to not have live migration abort on the first host.

Instead we should just switch to compareHypervisorCPU() and baselineHypervisorCPU() APIs, as this patch is doing per the proposed spec."}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2021-02-02 14:52:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

I suggest to split this out into a few patches for ease of reviewing.  Something along the lines of:

- libvirt: Introduce compare_hypervisor_cpu() method
- libvirt: Introduce baseline_hypervisor_cpu() method
- Rework _get_guest_cpu_model_config() method to take advantage of the new CPU APIs
- Update the get_capabilities() method to make use of baseline_hypervisor_cpu()
- Update the check_can_live_migrate_destination() method to use compare_hypervisor_cpu()
- ... # Probably more, if needed'}, {'account_id': 12203, 'date': '2021-02-03 10:29:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-11-11 10:57:42.000000000', 'message': "Add hypervisor CPU feature check during live migration

When the vm does not specify a host for live migration,
it will call libvirt's compareCPU() to compare cpu features,
which is not very useful. For example, when the kernel version
of the host is different, compareCPU() passes the check,
but in fact the cpu features of the host may be different,
When the vm is live migrated to this host, a startup error will occur.

In order to solve this problem, add hypervisor CPU feature check
during live migration.

Change-Id: Ied6529e9147a955c4c9afc1f2b31cb2829e58c65
Closes-Bug: #1903822

"}, {'created': '2020-11-23 01:52:51.000000000', 'message': 'CPU selection with hypervisor consideration

When the vm does not specify a host for live migration,
it will call libvirt's compareCPU() to compare cpu features,
which is not very useful. For example, when the kernel version
of the host is different, compareCPU() passes the check,
but in fact the cpu features of the host may be different,
When the vm is live migrated to this host, a startup error will occur.

Make Nova's guest CPU selection approach more effective and reliable by
introducing two new QEMU- and libvirt-based CPU configuration APIs:
baselineHypervisorCPU() and compareHypervisorCPU().  These new APIs are
more "hypervisor-literate" compared to the existing libvirt APIs that
Nova uses.  As in, the new APIs take into account what the "host
hypervisor" (meaning: KVM, QEMU, and what libvirt knows about the host)
is capable of.

Taking advantage of these newer APIs will allow Nova to make more

across different hosts.

'}, {'created': '2020-11-23 03:53:11.000000000', 'message': 'CPU selection with hypervisor consideration

When the vm does not specify a host for live migration,
it will call libvirt's compareCPU() to compare cpu features,
which is not very useful. For example, when the kernel version
of the host is different, compareCPU() passes the check,
but in fact the cpu features of the host may be different,
When the vm is live migrated to this host, a startup error will occur.

Make Nova's guest CPU selection approach more effective and reliable by
introducing two new QEMU- and libvirt-based CPU configuration APIs:
baselineHypervisorCPU() and compareHypervisorCPU().  These new APIs are
more "hypervisor-literate" compared to the existing libvirt APIs that
Nova uses.  As in, the new APIs take into account what the "host
hypervisor" (meaning: KVM, QEMU, and what libvirt knows about the host)
is capable of.

Taking advantage of these newer APIs will allow Nova to make more
well-informed decisions when determining CPU models that are compatible
across different hosts.

Change-Id: Ied6529e9147a955c4c9afc1f2b31cb2829e58c65
Closes-Bug: #1903822
Implements: blueprint cpu-selection-with-hypervisor-consideration

'}, {'created': '2021-03-09 17:19:47.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Use improved guest CPU config APIs

A year ago this was proposed as part of a spec[1].  But it can now make
sense as an "advanced bug-fix", as it is essentially fixing some of the
fundamental design limitations of the older CPU APIs — compareCPU() and
baselineCPU() — by replacing them with their more enlightened
counterparts: compareHypervisorCPU() and baselineHypervisorCPU().

Example real-world problem: The older compareCPU() API uses host
physical CPUID -- it has CPU features that KVM itself doesn't expose.
However, there are also some CPU features that KVM can emulate, but are
not present in the host CPUID.  This causes live migration failures on
certain hardware, due to CPU incompatibility.

This problem can be solved by either (a) Nova not calling the older
compareCPU() at all; or (b) using the newer API, compareHypervisorCPU(),
which reflects the CPUID that KVM it actually able to expose to the
guest.  Option-(a) is not sensible because it results in aborting live
migration on the first unsupported host.  Option-(b) is the only
sensible path forward.

            - - -

Also, from the "Problem description" from here[1]:

    The current guest CPU config libvirt APIs that Nova uses,
    compareCPU() and baselineCPU(), are "not very useful" [...] because
    they don't consider the capabilities of the "host hypervisor" (KVM,
    QEMU and details libvirt knows about the host).  More concretely,
    with the existing APIs, compareCPU() and baselineCPU(), there is no
    way to ask if a given CPU model plus CPU flags combination is
    supported by KVM and a specific QEMU binary on the host. [...]

The newer APIs are more "hypervisor-literate" compared to the existing
libvirt APIs that Nova uses.  As in, the new APIs take into account what
the "host hypervisor" (meaning: KVM, QEMU, and what libvirt knows about
the host) is capable of.  Taking advantage of these newer APIs will
allow Nova to make more well-informed decisions when determining CPU
models that are compatible across different hosts.  Details in[1].

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/70811da221035044e27
    — Add "CPU selection with hypervisor consideration" spec

[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/772917

Change-Id: Ied6529e9147a955c4c9afc1f2b31cb2829e58c65
Closes-Bug: #1903822
Implements: blueprint cpu-selection-with-hypervisor-consideration

'}, {'created': '2022-03-23 13:34:43.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Use improved guest CPU config APIs

A year ago this was proposed as part of a spec[1].  But it can now make
sense as an "advanced bug-fix", as it is essentially fixing some of the
fundamental design limitations of the older CPU APIs — compareCPU() and
baselineCPU() — by replacing them with their more enlightened
counterparts: compareHypervisorCPU() and baselineHypervisorCPU().

Example real-world problem: The older compareCPU() API uses host
physical CPUID -- it has CPU features that KVM itself doesn't expose.
However, there are also some CPU features that KVM can emulate, but are
not present in the host CPUID.  This causes live migration failures on
certain hardware, due to CPU incompatibility.

This problem can be solved by either (a) Nova not calling the older
compareCPU() at all; or (b) using the newer API, compareHypervisorCPU(),
which reflects the CPUID that KVM it actually able to expose to the
guest.  Option-(a) is not sensible because it results in aborting live
migration on the first unsupported host.  Option-(b) is the only
sensible path forward.

            - - -

Also, from the "Problem description" from here[1]:

    The current guest CPU config libvirt APIs that Nova uses,
    compareCPU() and baselineCPU(), are "not very useful" [...] because
    they don't consider the capabilities of the "host hypervisor" (KVM,
    QEMU and details libvirt knows about the host).  More concretely,
    with the existing APIs, compareCPU() and baselineCPU(), there is no
    way to ask if a given CPU model plus CPU flags combination is
    supported by KVM and a specific QEMU binary on the host. [...]

The newer APIs are more "hypervisor-literate" compared to the existing
libvirt APIs that Nova uses.  As in, the new APIs take into account what
the "host hypervisor" (meaning: KVM, QEMU, and what libvirt knows about
the host) is capable of.  Taking advantage of these newer APIs will
allow Nova to make more well-informed decisions when determining CPU
models that are compatible across different hosts.  Details in[1].

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/70811da221035044e27
    — Add "CPU selection with hypervisor consideration" spec

[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/772917

Change-Id: Ied6529e9147a955c4c9afc1f2b31cb2829e58c65

commit_message:
libvirt: Replace compareCPU() with compareHypervisorCPU()

This API compares a given CPU description with the CPU capabilities the
host hypervisor is able to provide.  It is more "hypervisor-literate"
than its older counterpart, compareCPU().

The new API takes into account what the "host hypervisor" (meaning: KVM,
QEMU, and what libvirt knows about the host) is capable of.  Taking
advantage of these newer APIs will allow Nova to make more well-informed
decisions when determining CPU models that are compatible across
different hosts.  Details in[1].

    - - -

Example real-world problem: The older compareCPU() API uses host
physical CPUID -- it has CPU features that KVM itself doesn't expose.
However, there are also some CPU features that KVM can emulate, but are
not present in the host CPUID.  This causes live migration failures on
certain hardware, due to CPU incompatibility.

This problem can be solved by either (a) Nova not calling the older
compareCPU() at all; or (b) using the newer API, compareHypervisorCPU(),
which reflects the CPUID that KVM it actually able to expose to the
guest.  Option-(a) is not sensible because it results in aborting live
migration on the first unsupported host.  Option-(b) is the only
sensible path forward.

    - - -

From the "Problem description" in the spec[1]:

    The current guest CPU config libvirt APIs that Nova uses,
    compareCPU() and baselineCPU(), are "not very useful" [...] because
    they don't consider the capabilities of the "host hypervisor" (KVM,
    QEMU and details libvirt knows about the host).  More concretely,
    with the existing APIs, compareCPU() and baselineCPU(), there is no
    way to ask if a given CPU model plus CPU flags combination is
    supported by KVM and a specific QEMU binary on the host. [...]

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/70811da221035044e27
    — Add "CPU selection with hypervisor consideration" spec

Implements: blueprint cpu-selection-with-hypervisor-consideration

Co-Authored-By: Chengsheng <chengsheng@chinatelecom.cn>
Change-Id: Ied6529e9147a955c4c9afc1f2b31cb2829e58c65
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add documentation to create monthly stable releases

Add a reference on how the release tooling can be used.
Add a bullet point to the meeting agenda.
Drop reference to milestones on launchpad, which are no longer being
used.

Change-Id: I66492a7c74a05849b35a157f7782a6596887427f

commit_message:
Don't ignore errors of 'apt-get update' command

This change fixes an issue with 'apt-get update' command and stop
container building with erroneous source repositories.

Change-Id: I5ce2eb66a647e1805f086aa37942bf5d13eb4106
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2022-06-07 08:15:09.000000000', 'message': "Don't install pinned setuptools with distro pip

We are seeing failures when using an updated setuptools version
installed together with distro pip on Ubuntu 22.04. Install the version
from u-c only when we are also installing pip from upstream.

Change-Id: Ibb6e9424e5794ccbf9a937d2eecfa3bf60ed312e
"}, {'created': '2022-06-07 09:39:28.000000000', 'message': "Don't install pinned setuptools with distro pip

installed together with distro pip on Ubuntu 22.04. Install the version

Change-Id: Ibb6e9424e5794ccbf9a937d2eecfa3bf60ed312e
"}, {'created': '2022-06-07 11:43:21.000000000', 'message': "Don't install pinned setuptools with distro pip

installed together with distro pip on Ubuntu 22.04. Install the version

Change-Id: Ibb6e9424e5794ccbf9a937d2eecfa3bf60ed312e
"}]
commit_message:
Don't install pinned setuptools with distro pip

We are seeing failures when using an updated setuptools version
installed together with distro pip on Ubuntu 22.04. Install the version
from u-c only when we are also installing pip from upstream.

Change-Id: Ibb6e9424e5794ccbf9a937d2eecfa3bf60ed312e

commit_message:
Add variable to requirements-check job

The use case is to run the requirements-check job on a trailing
deliverable, whose master branch is still the development branch
for the previous cycle, and thus who needs to use the stable branch
requirements, not master.

Add the 'requirements_branch' var which will default to zuul.branch

Change-Id: If2bfc21f2a06956a0142a6b056a151883348850c

to add a (non-voting) 3.10 job, and remove the 3.5, 3.6 and 3.9 jobs.

Change-Id: Ic6b29e0f70b71de25d6b1bee306a2608e59451c5

commit_message:
Update 'openstack-python3-charm-jobs' to latest Python

Modify 'openstack-python3-charm-jobs' so that it mimics the behavior of
the recently introduced 'openstack-python3-jobs' template, allowing us
to add a (non-voting) 3.10 job, and remove the 3.5, 3.6 and 3.9 jobs.

Originally by Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ic6b29e0f70b71de25d6b1bee306a2608e59451c5

commit_message:
Pin diskimage-builder version due to drop Python3.6

Since Ibdbcf459608711ac64e7fefb1707f6708d68e750 merged to master we
need to pin diskimage-builder to latest stable tag with support of
the Python3.6 until we move to CentOS9.

Change-Id: I9f9e381716611b71584ecf8b371f8b7f45c694ee
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-06-07 09:53:40.000000000', 'message': 'CI: make CentOS Stream 8 jobs non-voting

We keep CS8 jobs before we get CentOS Stream 9 support ready.

But we have situations where OpenStack projects fail due to lack of new
enough (3.8+) Python in CS8.

So let make them non-voting while we wait.

Change-Id: I32bef531896777bfb463bb401ebba1d488a16bf9
'}, {'created': '2022-06-08 08:49:46.000000000', 'message': 'CI: drop CentOS Stream 8 jobs

We kept CS8 jobs while waiting to get CentOS Stream 9 support ready.

But we have situations where OpenStack projects fail due to lack of new
enough (3.8+) Python in CS8.

Time to make CS8 go away.

Change-Id: I32bef531896777bfb463bb401ebba1d488a16bf9
'}, {'created': '2022-06-08 08:51:22.000000000', 'message': 'CI: drop CentOS Stream 8 jobs

commit_message:
CI: drop CentOS Stream 8 jobs

We kept CS8 jobs while waiting to get CentOS Stream 9 support ready.

But we have situations where OpenStack projects fail due to lack of new
enough (3.8+) Python in CS8.

Time to make CS8 go away.

Change-Id: I32bef531896777bfb463bb401ebba1d488a16bf9

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-06-07 09:20:41.000000000', 'message': 'Multipath Hardware path handling

Removes multipath base devices from consideration by
default, and instead allows the device-mapper device
managed by multipath to be picked up and utilized
instead.

In effect, allowing us to ignore standby paths *and*
leverage multiple concurrent IO paths if so offered
via ALUA.

In reality, anyone who has previously built IPA with
multipath tooling might not have encountered issues
previously because they used Active/Active SAN storage
environments. They would have worked because the IO lock
would have been exchanged between controllers and paths.
However, Active/Passive environments will block passive
paths from access, ultimately preventing new locks from
being established without proper negotiation. Ultimately
requiring multipathing *and* the agent to be smart enough
to know to disqualify underlying paths to backend storage
volumes.

An additional benefit of this is active/active MPIO devices
will, as long as ``multipath`` is present inside the ramdisk,
no longer possibly result in duplicate IO wipes occuring
accross numerous devices.

Task: #45108
Resolves: rhbz#2076622
Resolves: rhbz#2070519
Change-Id: I0fd6356f036d5ff17510fb838eaf418164cdfc92

commit_message:
Multipath Hardware path handling

Removes multipath base devices from consideration by
default, and instead allows the device-mapper device
managed by multipath to be picked up and utilized
instead.

In effect, allowing us to ignore standby paths *and*
leverage multiple concurrent IO paths if so offered
via ALUA.

In reality, anyone who has previously built IPA with
multipath tooling might not have encountered issues
previously because they used Active/Active SAN storage
environments. They would have worked because the IO lock
would have been exchanged between controllers and paths.
However, Active/Passive environments will block passive
paths from access, ultimately preventing new locks from
being established without proper negotiation. Ultimately
requiring multipathing *and* the agent to be smart enough
to know to disqualify underlying paths to backend storage
volumes.

An additional benefit of this is active/active MPIO devices
will, as long as ``multipath`` is present inside the ramdisk,
no longer possibly result in duplicate IO wipes occuring
accross numerous devices.

Story: #2010003
Task: #45108
Resolves: rhbz#2076622
Resolves: rhbz#2070519
Change-Id: I0fd6356f036d5ff17510fb838eaf418164cdfc92
(cherry picked from commit 014d37743a3b5694e0e2a3cabfafe885417172d5)
(cherry picked from commit 2c95ee45339dc910a6b29cb5e0f24a1f48898165)
(cherry picked from commit 3c9b1131320fb97e81af38fc7471f5dbc968ca12)

commit_message:
Do not try to guess EFI partition path by its number

The logic of adding a partition number to the device path does not work
for devicemapper devices (e.g. a multipath storage device).

Conflicts:
	ironic_python_agent/efi_utils.py
	ironic_python_agent/extensions/image.py
	ironic_python_agent/tests/unit/extensions/test_image.py
	ironic_python_agent/tests/unit/test_efi_utils.py

Change-Id: I9a445e847d282c50adfa4bad5e7136776861005d
(cherry picked from commit f09f6c9f1a09c7062d0450b3e0a4d3164fd53f7f)
(cherry picked from commit 12e03698874d3d51884fd0de3174fa7b56076852)

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-05-25 09:18:43.000000000', 'message': 'Defer flow deletion in openvswitch firewall

Reduces the deletion time of conjunction flows on hypervisors
where virtual machines reside which are part of a security
group that has remote security groups as target which contain
thousands of ports.

Without deferred deletion the agent will call ovs-ofctl several
hundred times in succession, during this time the agent will
block any new vm creation or neutron port modifications on this
hypervisor.

This patch has been tested using a single network with a single
vm with a security group that points to a remote security group
with 2000 ports.

During testing without the patch, the iteration time for deletion
was at around 500 seconds. After adding the patch to the l2 agent
on the test environment the same deletion time went down to
4 seconds.

Closes-Bug: #1975674
Change-Id: I46b1fe94b2e358f7f4b2cd4943a74ebaf84f51b8
'}, {'created': '2022-05-30 08:09:34.000000000', 'message': 'Defer flow deletion in openvswitch firewall

Reduces the deletion time of conjunction flows on hypervisors
where virtual machines reside which are part of a security
group that has remote security groups as target which contain
thousands of ports.

Without deferred deletion the agent will call ovs-ofctl several
hundred times in succession, during this time the agent will
block any new vm creation or neutron port modifications on this
hypervisor.

This patch has been tested using a single network with a single
vm with a security group that points to a remote security group
with 2000 ports.

During testing without the patch, the iteration time for deletion
was at around 500 seconds. After adding the patch to the l2 agent
on the test environment the same deletion time went down to
4 seconds.

Closes-Bug: #1975674
Change-Id: I46b1fe94b2e358f7f4b2cd4943a74ebaf84f51b8
'}]
commit_message:
Defer flow deletion in openvswitch firewall

Reduces the deletion time of conjunction flows on hypervisors
where virtual machines reside which are part of a security
group that has remote security groups as target which contain
thousands of ports.

Without deferred deletion the agent will call ovs-ofctl several
hundred times in succession, during this time the agent will
block any new vm creation or neutron port modifications on this
hypervisor.

This patch has been tested using a single network with a single
vm with a security group that points to a remote security group
with 2000 ports.

During testing without the patch, the iteration time for deletion
was at around 500 seconds. After adding the patch to the l2 agent
on the test environment the same deletion time went down to
4 seconds.

Closes-Bug: #1975674
Change-Id: I46b1fe94b2e358f7f4b2cd4943a74ebaf84f51b8

I tested this with U in my staging environment and it solves my problem, that response to / contains wrong href scheme of http, although haproxy in front is only listening to https.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-08-26 11:07:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28:

(1 comment)

> Patch Set 28:
> 
> (3 comments)
> 
> Just voicing my opinion, we're moving the api portion out of server. So I think that part deserves its own section. The neutron-rpc-server is still the neutron-server.
> 
> Does that make more sense?

The problem of that approach is deployers that are upgrading. As then there can be a confusion about what neutron-server is. As well as it would be harder to switch back and forth or at least this path would be not crystal clear.

Also current way we preserve neutron-server service to be API - either with uwsgi or with native way. And neutron-rpc service will be enabled only when we do uwsgi, otherwise it will be stopped and disabled."}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-08-26 14:12:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 29.'}, {'account_id': 25600, 'date': '2021-08-26 16:18:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29:

"name service differently with same exec" would be my point also. I similarly find it weird having neutron-api start in under the neutron-server service. Would there be a third option?

neutron_services:
  neutron-api:
    uwsgi_app: neutron_use_uwsgi
  neutron-server:
    service_en: !neutron_use_uwsgi
  neutron-rpc-server:
    service_en: neutron_use_uwsgi

the neutron-api gets filtered out by `filtered_neutron_services`,
neutron-rpc-server starts on use_uwsgi
and
neutron-server starts when use_uwsgi is false

I admit it gets a litte complicated, but the list in `neutron_services:` would atleast make more sense. They all belong to the neutron_server group, and will all start in the same neutron container anyways.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-08-26 16:56:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29:

> Patch Set 29:
> 
> "name service differently with same exec" would be my point also. I similarly find it weird having neutron-api start in under the neutron-server service. Would there be a third option?
> 
> neutron_services:
>   neutron-api:
>     uwsgi_app: neutron_use_uwsgi
>   neutron-server:
>     service_en: !neutron_use_uwsgi
>   neutron-rpc-server:
>     service_en: neutron_use_uwsgi
> 
> the neutron-api gets filtered out by `filtered_neutron_services`,
> neutron-rpc-server starts on use_uwsgi
> and
> neutron-server starts when use_uwsgi is false
> 
> I admit it gets a litte complicated, but the list in `neutron_services:` would atleast make more sense. They all belong to the neutron_server group, and will all start in the same neutron container anyways.

Then we would need to do the same with all other services that are done like that. Ie https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_glance/src/branch/master/defaults/main.yml#L275

If apply this logic, we would need to name all services that run with uwsgi by name of the wsgi scripts, which doesn't really make sense to me. And then same API service would have different name depedning if it's run with uwsgi or not.

So, I'd preffer to name services like the official documantation reference them, which states only neutron-server as for service that serves API [1][2]. So replacing neutron-server with neutron-api service would be at least pretty confusing.


[1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/install/controller-install-ubuntu.html#finalize-installation
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/install/common/get-started-networking.html'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-08-26 16:58:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Patch Set 29 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 25600, 'date': '2021-08-26 18:07:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

Thanks for taking the time to discuss this

> Then we would need to do the same with all other services that are done like that. Ie https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_glance/src/branch/master/defaults/main.yml#L275

Glance is only one service (uwsgi), and it's called glance-api

Have a look at cinder;
https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_cinder/src/branch/master/defaults/main.yml#L346
Or nova;
https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_nova/src/branch/master/defaults/main.yml#L426
Or keystone;
https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_keystone/src/branch/master/defaults/main.yml#L543

You see they ALL got their own -api service.

> If apply this logic, we would need to name all services that run with uwsgi by name of the wsgi scripts, which doesn't really make sense to me.

Seems to me only keystone has the weird keystone-wsgi-public name, the others are plainly called -api. But yes that happens to be the case for keystone, glance, cinder and nova. cinder and nova have multiple services and the api gets to be its own service.

> And then same API service would have different name depedning if it's run with uwsgi or not.

Neutron is the last of the "big-five" to actually split off it's api portion. How is the rpc-server more worthy of it's own service name?

> So, I'd preffer to name services like the official documantation reference them, which states only neutron-server as for service that serves API [1][2]. So replacing neutron-server with neutron-api service would be at least pretty confusing.

In the case we're deploying them as separate services it would be just as, if not more important that the rpc-server gets a restart, which is equally undocumented and confusing.


I think we both have made good arguments and points on this, would be good if we got a third core's opinion on the color of this bikeshed ;)'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-08-27 08:24:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-08-27 08:38:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 31: Patch Set 30 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-12-06 17:29:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 32: Patch Set 31 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-12-06 19:12:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 33: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-12-06 21:46:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 34: Published edit on patch set 33.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-12-07 06:02:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 35: Published edit on patch set 34.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-12-10 12:11:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 36: Published edit on patch set 35.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-12-10 12:11:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 37: Published edit on patch set 36.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2022-03-21 11:59:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 38.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2022-05-27 18:34:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39: Patch Set 38 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2022-06-08 08:13:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2022-06-08 08:52:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-07-21 14:12:08.000000000', 'message': 'Implement uWSGI for neutron-api

As part of the Pike goals we are moving api services to run as WSGI
apps. neutron-server service is set up as a wsgi app, and this patch
moves it over.

Since this is just a drop in replacement for the existing eventlet
service, operators an deployers should notice no difference.

Additionally, for Neutron, the logging method has been reworked for the
init scripts to match up with other roles.

Change-Id: Ia7ebd13be9ce7834679d439b7bda242805768ef8
Implements: blueprint goal-deploy-api-in-wsgi

commit_message:
Implement uWSGI for neutron-api

As part of the Pike goals we are moving api services to run as WSGI
apps. neutron-server service is set up as a wsgi app, and this patch
moves it over.

Since this is just a drop in replacement for the existing eventlet
service, operators an deployers should notice no difference.

Change-Id: Ia7ebd13be9ce7834679d439b7bda242805768ef8
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/820586
Implements: blueprint goal-deploy-api-in-wsgi

commit_message:
[glance] release 24.1.0 (yoga)

Release from stable/yoga; bumps Image service API to 2.16 and
includes corrected success response code for the cache-put
request.  Backport of this change was approved by the openstack
stable-maint team [0].

commit_message:
New option default_authorization_ttl

Add new option default_authorization_ttl used for
federation to set validity of group memberships
coming from a mapping.

Closes-Bug: #1970388

(cherry picked from commit f5d9b9ed4095a46be0ba0067ace7bf1c93bdfd8b)

commit_message:
Update python testing as per zed cycle testing runtime

In Zed cycle, we have dropped the python 3.6/3.7[1] testing
and its support. Add release notes and update the python
classifier for the same.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/zed.html

Co-Authored-By: Ghanshyam Mann <gmann@ghanshyammann.com>
Change-Id: I998b34f884a2869d46ff05a179708a7f775e1615

commit_message:
Remove stable/victoria job and fixing job description

As we have pinned Tempest and cinder-temest-plugin in EM
stable/victoria, we do not need to test those in master
gate, so removing the stable/victoria job from master gate.

Also, fixing the comment about job description update from
- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder-tempest-plugin/+/843319/1/.zuul.yaml#119

Change-Id: I721a494aa52129c58683f36853bc2fd064df48eb

subject: Check mysql-router pkg version and adjust ssl option
revisions:
[{'created': '2022-06-08 09:23:30.000000000', 'message': "Check mysql-router pkg version and adjust ssl option

Only affect mysql-router >= 8.0.23
If there is no client_ssl_cert, remove client_ssl_mode anyway.

Removing _parameters's pid_file as it causes error after rebooting

Change-Id: I4354a3128dedfa90d4ea806fe98f5a400e4fa896
"}]
commit_message:
Check mysql-router pkg version and adjust ssl option

Only affect mysql-router >= 8.0.23
If there is no client_ssl_cert, remove client_ssl_mode anyway.

Removing _parameters's pid_file as it causes error after rebooting

Change-Id: I4354a3128dedfa90d4ea806fe98f5a400e4fa896

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-06-03 03:53:03.000000000', 'message': 'Allow to skip stop of ovn services

Grenade jobs stop services, check fip connectivity
for a nova server and then upgrade to next release.

But since ovn data plane and db services are stopped along
with other services, fip connectivity fails as a result.

We shouldn't stop these services along with other
neutron services. This patch adds a new variable
"SKIP_STOP_OVN" which can be used by grenade jobs
to skip stop of ovn services.

This will also fix the ovn grenade jobs.

Also source fixup_stuff.sh so function fixup_ovn_centos
is available. It's already sourced in stack.sh but
that's not used in grenade run.

Change-Id: I94818a19f19973779cb2e11753d2881d54dfa3bc
(cherry picked from commit 6f545e2567166ed9790601ccb589307df688d40d)
'}]
commit_message:
Allow to skip stop of ovn services

Grenade jobs stop services, check fip connectivity
for a nova server and then upgrade to next release.

But since ovn data plane and db services are stopped along
with other services, fip connectivity fails as a result.

We shouldn't stop these services along with other
neutron services. This patch adds a new variable
"SKIP_STOP_OVN" which can be used by grenade jobs
to skip stop of ovn services.

This will also fix the ovn grenade jobs.

Also source fixup_stuff.sh so function fixup_ovn_centos
is available. It's already sourced in stack.sh but
that's not used in grenade run.

Change-Id: I94818a19f19973779cb2e11753d2881d54dfa3bc
(cherry picked from commit 6f545e2567166ed9790601ccb589307df688d40d)

commit_message:
propose-updates: Run ensure-python for python 3.9

The propose-updates jobs needs both python 3.8 and 3.9. Python 3.8 is
installed anyway, so let's make sure python 3.9 is installed, too.

Change-Id: I0ceb754bc670382d38b7aed11a6aec97ccdfdf93

subject: Increase openstack-exporter timeout to 45 seconds
messages: [{'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2022-06-03 11:04:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2022-06-06 09:05:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2022-06-08 05:58:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2022-06-03 11:04:40.000000000', 'message': 'Increase openstack-exporter timeout to 45 seconds

Even on moderately sized clouds, openstack-exporter can easily take more
than 10 seconds to return, causing Prometheus to fail to scrape data.

Since the default scrape internal is 60 seconds, we can increase the
default timeout to 45 seconds.

Change-Id: Id8dffc425ff057b1e45103eb53734543bca8be80
Closes-Bug: #1976629
(cherry picked from commit 9653ebe102985e9ce0184d63a51e27152311e9cf)
'}]
commit_message:
Increase openstack-exporter timeout to 45 seconds

Even on moderately sized clouds, openstack-exporter can easily take more
than 10 seconds to return, causing Prometheus to fail to scrape data.

Since the default scrape internal is 60 seconds, we can increase the
default timeout to 45 seconds.

Change-Id: Id8dffc425ff057b1e45103eb53734543bca8be80
Closes-Bug: #1976629
(cherry picked from commit 9653ebe102985e9ce0184d63a51e27152311e9cf)

commit_message:
Enable hacluster role when it is needed

Masakari-hostmonitor needs to have
corosync/pacemaker deployed.

This patch is just changing default enable_hacluter: "no"
to "yes" if masakari-hostmonitor is enabled.

Closes-Bug: #1934149
Change-Id: I979d1d6d08ca0cc0a748f175da77f68bcecc2d1a

[{'created': '2022-02-07 09:26:54.000000000', 'message': 'Fix issue with LDAP backend returning bytes instead of string

When connecting to some LDAP server software, the ldap client returns
bytes instances instead of the expected strings. This can result in
either being transparently converted to strings, when the data is
inserted via sqlalchemy into the database, or could be used as
input to other functions, and/or cached, which causes unexpected
results.

Closes-Bug: #1952458
Resolves: rhbz#1964872
Change-Id: I77148641715efe09e3adc2e9432e66e50fb444b4
(cherry picked from commit 1e0cd90191663c100c165d4c6a2b1ca796b5af25)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix issue with LDAP backend returning bytes instead of string

When connecting to some LDAP server software, the ldap client returns
bytes instances instead of the expected strings. This can result in
either being transparently converted to strings, when the data is
inserted via sqlalchemy into the database, or could be used as
input to other functions, and/or cached, which causes unexpected
results.

Closes-Bug: #1952458
Resolves: rhbz#1964872
Change-Id: I77148641715efe09e3adc2e9432e66e50fb444b4
(cherry picked from commit 1e0cd90191663c100c165d4c6a2b1ca796b5af25)

commit_message:
Use libvirt automatic firmware for UEFI boot mode

This change switches to automatic firmware selection[1] available
since libvirt-5.3.0 to simplify setup for UEFI boot.

get_boot_mode will detect the boot mode with both the old manual os
XML, and the new automatic XML.

set_boot_mode will convert old manual XML to the new automatic XML.

As described in the "Secure boot woes" section of [2], the secure
attribute does not actually change the firmware path to the
(non)secure version of the firmware binary, so the loader path still
needs to be explicit until libvirt supports a secure selection
mechanism (tracked by [3])

[1] https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#bios-bootloader
[2] https://that.guru/blog/uefi-secure-boot-in-libvirt/
[3] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1937150

Change-Id: I586dc220f9a49b9ae2be2bf40939c321ad877751

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-05-27 02:55:25.000000000', 'message': 'Implement set_secure_boot for libvirt driver

The previous change switched to the automatic firmware XML format, so
setting the secure boot state is simply setting the secure attribute
on the loader element (instead of changing a distro-specific file
path).

Just like the boot mode behaviour, getting the secure boot status
works with both the old manual and new automatic formats. Also setting
the secure boot status will also upgrade existing old manual XML to
the automatic format.

Change-Id: Ie7f9df566e13081f1113b5bc367c711578762ec8
'}, {'created': '2022-05-31 01:52:39.000000000', 'message': 'Implement set_secure_boot for libvirt driver

The loader path values in SUSHY_EMULATOR_BOOT_LOADER_MAP can now
optionally contain a list of filenames instead of a single string
filename. When switching secure boot mode, the first path is the
non-secure boot loader, and the second is the secure boot loader.
SUSHY_EMULATOR_BOOT_LOADER_MAP values can still be a string or None.

Just like the boot mode behaviour, getting the secure boot status
works with both the old manual and new automatic formats. Also setting
the secure boot status will also upgrade existing old manual XML to
the automatic format.

Change-Id: Ie7f9df566e13081f1113b5bc367c711578762ec8
'}, {'created': '2022-05-31 04:42:25.000000000', 'message': 'Implement set_secure_boot for libvirt driver

filename. When switching secure boot mode, the first path is the
non-secure boot loader, and the second is the secure boot loader.
SUSHY_EMULATOR_BOOT_LOADER_MAP values can still be a string or None.

Just like the boot mode behaviour, getting the secure boot status

the automatic format.

Change-Id: Ie7f9df566e13081f1113b5bc367c711578762ec8
